book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: As in a chess problem, you have to plan a few moves in advance.
solution_line: If you play routinely, ruffing a club and finessing in trumps, the opponents may wise up and find a club ruff. Instead, play the ten of trumps at trick 2.
result_comparison: Your partners sacrificed in spades against four hearts. Down three: +500 for EW. You played ♥10: +620 = +3 IMP. You ruffed a club: –12 IMP.
additional_notes: Play the ten of trumps at trick 2 to avoid opponents finding a club ruff.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: A small chance is better than nothing.
solution_line: 1-3. Duck the ten of diamonds, win the second diamond and play ♠9. South covers with ♠10, king from your hand and North follows with ♠7! 4-5. A heart to the jack, South wins with the ace and plays a spade, won with the king. 6. Play a club from the dummy – luckily, South covers again. After playing low by South playing 6♠ is risky. You may go down if clubs break 3-2.You have to ask yourself a question whether there is another distribution of cards when a high-class defender will rise with 10♣ and play 5♣ in the second club trick. Those players who did not spot the chance of a singleton ♣7 with North played the ace and king of clubs, could not make the contract.
result_comparison: The Austrians made 3NT after a spade lead (and not the best defence). Result: +600 for EW. You spotted the chance of a singleton ♠7: no swing. If not: –12 IMP.
additional_notes: You have to ask yourself a question whether there is another distribution of cards when a high-class defender will rise with 10♠ and play 5♠ in the second club trick. Those players who did not spot the chance of a singleton ♠7 with North played the ace and king of clubs, could not make the contract.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Do not give up, there is a layout that will let you make the contract.
solution_line: You know the distribution of diamonds from the opening lead. Play all your tricks, watching the opponents' discards carefully. If you find the king of hearts with North and the jack of hearts with South then in a three-card ending they both have to keep two hearts and a diamond. Play a diamond and make the contract! But be careful, one of the opponents may bare his heart honour. This is a big risk. You will have to watch the discards very carefully!
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT, +460 for EW. You found the winning line: +920 = +10 IMP. If not: –11 IMP.
additional_notes: Watch the opponents' discards carefully in the three-card ending.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
opening_lead: ♦K, ♦Q - South overtakes with the ace and plays ♦J
key_insight: Information about the distribution of a diamond suit, which is seemingly irrelevant, may be decisive for declarer's play.
solution_line: The idea of ruffing the third diamond with the jack of hearts is a bit far-fetched. Order of play: 3. Ruff the third heart low. There is a serious threat is trump promotion if A-x-x of hearts is with five diamonds. A) if North holds five diamonds then you have to leads towards the K-Q of hearts; B) if South holds five diamonds then cross to the dummy with a spade and play a heart to the jack. The way South played in diamonds makes variant b) seems more likely.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♥, Lead 6♠, +420 for EW. You played to the jack of hearts: no swing. You played a heart to the king: –10 IMP.
additional_notes: Consider the distribution of diamonds to determine the best heart play.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Win the heart lead 2-3. Cross to dummy with a spade and play a club, discarding a diamond if South does not cover with an honour. If South covers in clubs, you may have to repeat this manoeuvre once or twice more. The weak 2♥ opener should not hold three club honours because he has already disclosed three heart honours. You may ask what if South opened with five hearts and North bluffed by leading the lower card from the doubleton? It will be my pleasure to buy such a pair in the Cavendish tournament in Las Vegas.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 6♠, +1370 for EW. You noticed that the diamond suit was blocked: +2 IMP. If not: –16 IMP.
additional_notes: The weak 2♥ opener should not hold three club honours.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
solution_line: Order of play: 3-4. Ruff and play a spade to the ten. If you lose to the jack there is still the chance of a diamond finesse. Your team mates were doubled in 3♥x, down two, +300 for EW. A spade to the ten: +130 = –5 IMP If you played it differently: –8 IMP.
result_comparison: Your team mates were doubled in 3♥x, down two, +300 for EW. A spade to the ten: +130 = –5 IMP If you played it differently: –8 IMP.
additional_notes: If the spade finesse loses, you still have the diamond finesse as a backup chance.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Your line of play is determined by your communication problems.
solution_line: After winning with the ace you have to notice that you cannot enter the dummy three times in trumps because you need two trumps to ruff clubs. Order of play: 1. Win the ace of spades. 2-4. Play the ace, king and a small diamond. You will have a dilemma here, if South follows suit: 1) if you ruff with a small card you will make it if diamonds break 3-3, hearts may even be 3-0. 2) if you ruff with the king you win if diamonds break 3-3 and hearts 2-1, or diamonds are 4-2 and a single heart is with the doubleton diamond. After ruffing with the king of hearts, cross to the trump ace and ruff a diamond. The play is well in line with the odds in variant b), simply because the opponents did not bid, which implies a more even distribution of the suits than normal.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♥, +450 for EW. You played as above: +980 = +11 IMP. Otherwise: –11 IMP.
additional_notes: The opponents did not bid, which implies a more even distribution of the suits than normal.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
opening_lead: ♦4, South opened 1 Dia. South wins ♠A and plays ♦Q
key_insight: Your hand is faster than your head. Think before you play.
solution_line: The only risk is that North holds four trumps and a singleton diamond. Duck the queen of diamonds. If South plays a third diamond, cover in your hand, not worrying if North ruffs higher than dummy's five with his long trumps.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♠ doubled, +790 for the Austrians. You ducked the queen of diamonds: +620 = –5 IMP. Your hand was faster than your head: –13 IMP.
additional_notes: Don't let North ruff higher than dummy's trumps if he has long trumps and a singleton diamond.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Before taking the obvious line, check other options.
solution_line: It seems that the contract depends on the successful spade finesse. However, try leading the queen of diamonds at trick 2. a) if North covers with the king the king – great. Draw trumps and a new option (four heart tricks) appears. b) if North plays low, rise with the ace for a chance of single king. c) if South plays low, you still can play for the king of spades finesse.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT (E) after a spade opening lead +490 for the Austrians. You made the contract: +920 = +10 IMP. You played for a spade finesse at trick 2: –11 IMP.
additional_notes: Try leading the queen of diamonds to create additional chances before falling back on the spade finesse.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship - part 1
author: K. Martens
opening_lead: ♦5, East opened 1♣ and South doubled. South wins ♦K, plays ♦A, ♠Q
key_insight: Look for even the slightest chance.
solution_line: Order of play: 3-4. Win the ace in the dummy and play the queen of hearts. Why? The bidding shows that South holds three or four hearts. If they break 4-1 you will make it when singleton 8, 9, or 10 is with North.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♥, +420 for the Austrians. You played the queen of hearts: no swing. If not: –10 IMP.
additional_notes: The bidding indicates South has 3-4 hearts, so playing the queen gives you the best chance if hearts break 4-1 with a singleton honor in North. You could win this difficult match with +26 IMP = 20-10 VP. In Round 16 you will face Ukraine.
